description.value:
Elves are a magical people of otherworldly grace, living in the world but not entirely part of it.

Racial Traits
+2 Dexterity, @toggleEffect[Darkvision], Keen Senses, Fey Ancestry, Trance

Dusk elves are a rare subset of elves native to the Domains of Dread and are all but extinct.  Like most elves, dusk elves are lithe and slender in build, with angular features and long pointed ears. However, they have dark skin that ranges from a lighter grey color to a dark, charcoal black, much like drow. Unlike drow, they have black hair and tend to have matching dark eyes.

Age. No dusk elf child has been born since the execution of all their women. As such, a dusk elf character from Barovia has a minimum age of about 250 years.

Gender: Current dusk elves are biologically male and incapable of bearing children. However, it is possible through some story means or magical fluke that a dusk elf female may have avoided the purge of their women. If your character is biologically female, speak to your DM to determine how they survived or avoided the executions.

@toggleEffect[Darkvision]

Accustomed to twilit forests and the night sky, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can’t discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

@Compendium[adv-with-droop.race-traits.O8sJuOr18adAfwrz]{Keen Senses}

You have proficiency in the @Compendium[dnd5e.rules.0AGfrwZRzSG0vNKb]{Perception} skill.

Fey Ancestry

You have advantage on saving throws against being @toggleEffect[Charmed], and magic can’t put you to sleep.

@Compendium[adv-with-droop.race-traits.9TBrHuuYadp5TKb9]{Trance}

Elves don’t need to sleep. Instead, they meditate deeply, remaining semiconscious, for 4 hours a day. (The Common word for such meditation is “trance.”) While meditating, you can dream after a fashion; such dreams are actually mental exercises that have become reflexive through years of practice. After resting in this way, you gain the same benefit that a human does from 8 hours of sleep.

Ability Score Increase

Your Dexterity score increases by 2.

Languages

You can speak, read, and write Common and Elvish. Elvish is fluid, with subtle intonations and intricate grammar. Elven literature is rich and varied, and their songs and poems are famous among other races. Many bards learn their language so they can add Elvish ballads to their repertoires.

Age

Although elves reach physical maturity at about the same age as humans, the elven understanding of adulthood goes beyond physical growth to encompass worldly experience. An elf typically claims adulthood and an adult name around the age of 100 and can live to be 750 years old.

Size

Elves range from under 5 to over 6 feet tall and have slender builds. Your size is Medium.

Speed

Your base walking speed is 30 feet.

@Compendium[adv-with-droop.race-traits.5fqd66mgnaSasaVB]{Dusk Elf Weapon Training}

You have proficiency with the hand crossbow, light crossbow, shortbow, and longbow.

Ability Score Increase

Your Charisma score increases by 1.

@Compendium[adv-with-droop.race-traits.t09R01AXRWcUYDjj]{Fleet of Foot}

Your base walking speed increases to 35 feet

@Compendium[adv-with-droop.race-traits.WdIzXQESyvoBIBMX]{Mask of the Shadows}

You have advantage on Dexterity (@Compendium[dnd5e.rules.0AGfrwZRzSG0vNKb]{Stealth}) checks when you are attempting to hide within darkness or in heavily obscured, natural environments such as foliage, heavy rain, falling snow, and mist.

Whispering to the spirits of @Compendium[dnd5e.rules.0AGfrwZRzSG0vNKb]{nature}, you create one of the following effects within range:

  • You create a tiny, harmless sensory effect that predicts what the weather will be at your location for the next 24 hours. The effect might manifest as a golden orb for clear skies, a cloud for rain, falling snowflakes for snow, and so on. This effect persists for 1 round.
  • You instantly make a flower blossom, a seed pod open, or a leaf bud bloom.
  • You create an instantaneous, harmless sensory effect, such as falling leaves, a puff of wind, the sound of a small animal, or the faint odor of skunk. The effect must fit in a 5-foot cube.
  • You instantly light or snuff out a candle, a torch, or a small campfire.
While wearing this cloak, you can use a bonus action to make it billow dramatically.
Proficiency with a greatsword allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

You hurl a mote of &Reference[fire]{fire} at a creature or object within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes 1d10 &Reference[fire]{fire} damage. A flammable object hit by this spell ignites if it isn't being worn or carried.

This spell's damage increases by 1d10 when you reach 5th level (2d10), 11th level (3d10), and 17th level (4d10).

Description

A priest of the Old Faith, wielding the powers of &Reference[nat]{nature} and adopting animal forms

Hit Die: d8
Primary Ability: &Reference[wis]{Wisdom}
Saves: &Reference[int]{Intelligence} & &Reference[wis]{Wisdom}

Class Features

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.oFwQeCWJrleFAtBc]{Equipment}

You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

  • (a) a wooden shield or (b) any simple weapon
  • (a) a scimitar or (b) any simple melee weapon
  • Leather armor, an explorer’s pack, and a druidic focus

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.RlohOvfpfHMuDCNN]{Druidic}

You know Druidic, the secret language of druids. You can speak the language and use it to leave hidden messages. You and others who know this language automatically spot such a message. Others spot the message’s presence with a successful DC 15 &Reference[wis]{Wisdom} (&Reference[prc]{Perception}) check but can’t decipher it without magic.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.0nz372prjDZpdwA8]{Spellcasting}

Drawing on the divine essence of &Reference[nat]{nature} itself, you can cast spells to shape that essence to your will. See Spells Rules for the general rules of spellcasting and the Spells Listing for the druid spell list.

Cantrips

At 1st level, you know two cantrips of your choice from the druid spell list. You learn additional druid cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the Druid table.

Preparing and Casting Spells

The Druid table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your druid spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these druid spells, you must expend a slot of the spell’s level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

You prepare the list of druid spells that are available for you to cast, choosing from the druid spell list. When you do so, choose a number of druid spells equal to your &Reference[wis]{Wisdom} modifier + your druid level (minimum of one spell). The spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

For example, if you are a 3rd-level druid, you have four 1st-level and two 2nd-level spell slots. With a &Reference[wis]{Wisdom} of 16, your list of prepared spells can include six spells of 1st or 2nd level, in any combination. If you prepare the 1st-level spell cure wounds, you can cast it using a 1st-level or 2nd-level slot. Casting the spell doesn’t remove it from your list of prepared spells.

You can also change your list of prepared spells when you finish a long rest. Preparing a new list of druid spells requires time spent in prayer and meditation: at least 1 minute per spell level for each spell on your list.

Spellcasting Ability

&Reference[wis]{Wisdom} is your spellcasting ability for your druid spells, since your magic draws upon your devotion and attunement to &Reference[nat]{nature}. You use your &Reference[wis]{Wisdom} whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your &Reference[wis]{Wisdom} modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a druid spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your &Reference[wis]{Wisdom} modifier

Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your &Reference[wis]{Wisdom} modifier

&Reference[ritual]{Ritual} Casting

You can cast a druid spell as a &Reference[ritual]{ritual} if that spell has the &Reference[ritual]{ritual} tag and you have the spell prepared.

Spellcasting Focus

You can use a druidic focus (see the Adventuring Gear section) as a spellcasting focus for your druid spells.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.Z4AQOFjSiaYf3izF]{Wild Shape}

Starting at 2nd level, you can use your action to magically assume the shape of a &Reference[beast]{beast} that you have seen before. You can use this feature twice. You regain expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

Your druid level determines the beasts you can transform into, as shown in the &Reference[beast]{Beast} Shapes table. At 2nd level, for example, you can transform into any &Reference[beast]{beast} that has a challenge rating of 1/4 or lower that doesn’t have a flying or swimming speed.

&Reference[beast]{Beast} Shapes

Level

Max CR

Limitations

Example

2nd

1/4

No flying or swimming speed

Wolf

4th

1/2

No flying speed

Crocodile

8th

1

—

&Reference[giant]{Giant} eagle


You can stay in a &Reference[beast]{beast} shape for a number of hours equal to half your druid level (rounded down). You then revert to your normal form unless you expend another use of this feature. You can revert to your normal form earlier by using a bonus action on your turn. You automatically revert if you fall &Reference[unconscious]{unconscious}, drop to 0 hit points, or die.

While you are transformed, the following rules apply:

  • Your game statistics are replaced by the statistics of the &Reference[beast]{beast}, but you retain your alignment, personality, and &Reference[int]{Intelligence}, &Reference[wis]{Wisdom}, and &Reference[cha]{Charisma} scores. You also retain all of your skill and saving throw proficiencies, in addition to gaining those of the creature. If the creature has the same proficiency as you and the bonus in its stat block is higher than yours, use the creature’s bonus instead of yours. If the creature has any legendary or lair actions, you can’t use them.
  • When you transform, you assume the beast’s hit points and Hit Dice. When you revert to your normal form, you return to the number of hit points you had before you transformed. However, if you revert as a result of dropping to 0 hit points, any excess damage carries over to your normal form. For example, if you take 10 damage in animal form and have only 1 hit point left, you revert and take 9 damage. As long as the excess damage doesn’t reduce your normal form to 0 hit points, you aren’t knocked &Reference[unconscious]{unconscious}.
  • You can’t cast spells, and your ability to speak or take any action that requires hands is limited to the capabilities of your &Reference[beast]{beast} form. Transforming doesn’t break your &Reference[concentration]{concentration} on a spell you’ve already cast, however, or prevent you from taking actions that are part of a spell, such as call &Reference[lightning]{lightning}, that you’ve already cast.
  • You retain the benefit of any features from your class, race, or other source and can use them if the new form is physically capable of doing so. However, you can’t use any of your special senses, such as &Reference[darkvision]{darkvision}, unless your new form also has that sense.
  • You choose whether your equipment falls to the ground in your space, merges into your new form, or is worn by it. Worn equipment functions as normal, but the DM decides whether it is practical for the new form to wear a piece of equipment, based on the creature’s shape and size. Your equipment doesn’t change size or shape to match the new form, and any equipment that the new form can’t wear must either fall to the ground or merge with it. Equipment that merges with the form has no effect until you leave the form.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.6LkJGpqUKaQ6R1hm]{Druid Circle}

At 2nd level, you choose to identify with a circle of druids: the Circle of the Land detailed at the end of the class description or one from the Player's Handbook or other sources. Your choice grants you features at 2nd level and again at 6th, 10th, and 14th level.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.QuQUo8JDVg4Vr6oN]{Wild Shape Improvement}

At 4th level, you can use your action to magically assume the shape of a &Reference[beast]{beast} that you have seen before of challenge rating 1/2 or lower that doesn't have a flying speed. You can use this feature twice. You regain expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.Beb11yFpNdYdFBMk]{Ability Score Improvement}

When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.6Ard3FVKgmfBGUPh]{Timeless Body}

Starting at 18th level, the primal magic that you wield causes you to age more slowly. For every 10 years that pass, your body ages only 1 year.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.IOdFAZwcfl9qOpcz]{Beast Spells}

Beginning at 18th level, you can cast many of your druid spells in any shape you assume using Wild Shape. You can perform the &Reference[somatic]{somatic} and &Reference[vocal]{verbal} components of a druid spell while in a &Reference[beast]{beast} shape, but you aren’t able to provide &Reference[material]{material} components.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.fPvPvaNTJGZRGZrx]{Archdruid}

At 20th level, you can use your Wild Shape an unlimited number of times.

Additionally, you can ignore the &Reference[vocal]{verbal} and &Reference[somatic]{somatic} components of your druid spells, as well as any &Reference[material]{material} components that lack a cost and aren’t consumed by a spell. You gain this benefit in both your normal shape and your &Reference[beast]{beast} shape from Wild Shape.

Starting Equipment

You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

  • (a) a wooden shield or (b) any simple weapon
  • (a) a scimitar or (b) any simple melee weapon
  • Leather armor, an explorer’s pack, and a druidic focus

Description

A priest of the Old Faith, wielding the powers of &Reference[nat]{nature} and adopting animal forms

Hit Die: d8
Primary Ability: &Reference[wis]{Wisdom}
Saves: &Reference[int]{Intelligence} & &Reference[wis]{Wisdom}

Class Features

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.dDsCI8gcQUd5jYHp]{Combat Wild Shape}

When you choose this circle at 2nd level, you gain the ability to use Wild Shape on your turn as a bonus action, rather than as an action.

Additionally, while you are transformed by Wild Shape, you can use a bonus action to expend one spell slot to regain 1d8 hit points per level of the spell slot expended.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.2rpKNQdnGA9IjoCn]{Circle Forms}

The rites of your circle grant you the ability to transform into more dangerous animal forms. Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Wild Shape to transform into a &Reference[beast]{beast} with a challenge rating as high as 1 (you ignore the Max. CR column of the &Reference[beast]{Beast} Shapes table, but must abide by the other limitations there).

Starting at 6th level, you can transform into a &Reference[beast]{beast} with a challenge rating as high as your druid level divided by 3, rounded down.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.uT3ep0DdBhUCmVv1]{Primal Strike}

Starting at 6th level, your attacks in &Reference[beast]{beast} form count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.plzsgQ8wTiqUW5Wt]{Elemental Wild Shape}

At 10th level, you can expend two uses of Wild Shape at the same time to transform into an air &Reference[elemental]{elemental}, an earth &Reference[elemental]{elemental}, a &Reference[fire]{fire} &Reference[elemental]{elemental}, or a water &Reference[elemental]{elemental}.

@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.class-feats.Item.ntnhLeQoOeGuSTpR]{Thousand Forms}

By 14th level, you have learned to use magic to alter your physical form in more subtle ways. You can cast the alter self spell at will.

Increase your INT score by 1. You learn three languages of your choice. You can create written ciphers that others can't decipher unless you teach them, they succeed on an INT check (DC + [[@prof+ @abilities.int.value]]), or they use magic to decipher it.
More Details

You have studied languages and codes, gaining the following benefits:

  • Increase your &Reference[int]{Intelligence} score by 1, to a maximum of 20.
  • You learn three languages of your choice.
  • You can ably create written ciphers. Others can't decipher a code you create unless you teach them, they succeed on an &Reference[int]{Intelligence} check (DC equal to your &Reference[int]{Intelligence} score + your proficiency bonus), or they use magic to decipher it.

You can transform into a &Reference[beast]{beast} with a CR as high as [[floor( + @classes.druid.levels/3)]].
More Details

The rites of your circle grant you the ability to transform into more dangerous animal forms. Starting at 6th level, you can transform into a &Reference[beast]{beast} with a challenge rating as high as your druid level divided by 3, rounded down.

Your attacks in &Reference[beast]{beast} form count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

More Details

You have studied languages and codes, gaining the following benefits:

  • Increase your &Reference[int]{Intelligence} score by 1, to a maximum of 20.
  • You learn three languages of your choice.
  • You can ably create written ciphers. Others can't decipher a code you create unless you teach them, they succeed on an &Reference[int]{Intelligence} check (DC equal to your &Reference[int]{Intelligence} score + your proficiency bonus), or they use magic to decipher it.

description.value:
Background: Haunted One

You are haunted by something so terrible that you dare not speak of it. You’ve tried to bury it and run away from it, to no avail. Whatever this thing is that haunts you can’t be slain with a sword or banished with a spell. It might come to you as a shadow on the wall, a bloodcurdling nightmare, a memory that refuses to die, or a demonic whisper in the dark. The burden has taken its toll, isolating you from most people and making you question your sanity. You must find a way to overcome it before it destroys you.

Skill Proficiencies: Choose two from among &Reference[arc]{Arcana}, &Reference[inv]{Investigation}, &Reference[rel]{Religion}, or &Reference[sur]{Survival}

Languages: Choose two, one of which must be Abyssal, &Reference[celestial]{Celestial}, Deep Speech, Draconic, Infernal, Primordial, Sylvan, or Undercommon

Equipment: A monster hunter’s pack (containing a chest, a crowbar, a hammer, three wooden stakes, a holy symbol, a flask of holy water, a set of manacles, a steel mirror, a flask of oil, a tinderbox, and 3 torches), one trinket of special significance (choose one or roll on the Horror Trinkets table after this background), a set of common clothes, and 1 sp.

Harrowing Event

Prior to becoming an adventurer, your path in life was defined by one dark moment, one fateful decision, or one tragedy. Now you feel a darkness threatening to consume you, and you fear there may be no hope of escape. Choose a harrowing event that haunts you, or roll one on the Harrowing Events table.

Harrowing Event
d10 Event
1 A monster that slaughtered dozens of innocent people spared your life, and you don’t know why.
2 You were born under a dark star. You can feel it watching you, coldly and distantly. Sometimes it beckons you in the dead of night.
3 An apparition that has haunted your family for generations now haunts you. You don’t know what it wants, and it won’t leave you alone.
4 Your family has a &Reference[his]{history} of practicing the dark arts. You dabbled once and felt something horrible clutch at your soul, whereupon you fled in terror.
5 An oni took your sibling one &Reference[cold]{cold}, dark night, and you were unable to stop it.
6 You were cursed with lycanthropy and later cured. You are now haunted by the innocents you slaughtered.
7 A hag kidnapped and raised you. You escaped, but the hag still has a magical hold over you and fills your mind with evil thoughts.
8 You opened an eldritch tome and saw things unfit for a sane mind. You burned the book, but its words and images are burned into your psyche.
9 A &Reference[fiend]{fiend} possessed you as a child. You were locked away but escaped. The &Reference[fiend]{fiend} is still inside you, but now you try to keep it bottled up.
10 You did terrible things to avenge the murder of someone you loved. You became a monster, and it haunts your waking dreams.
@UUID[Compendium.adv-with-droop.roll-tables.RollTable.hlYcRpUqlhNW7hG7]{Open RollTable Background: Haunted One: Harrowing Event}

Heart of Darkness

Those who look into your eyes can see that you have faced unimaginable horror and that you are no stranger to darkness. Though they might fear you, commoners will extend you every courtesy and do their utmost to help you. Unless you have shown yourself to be a danger to them, they will even take up arms to fight alongside you, should you find yourself facing an enemy alone.

Proficiencies

  • Religion
  • Sylvan
  • Investigation
  • Infernal

You can punch, kick, head-butt, or use a similar forceful blow and deal &Reference[bludgeoning]{bludgeoning} damage equal to 1 + STR modifier
More Details

Instead of using a weapon to make a melee weapon attack, you can use an unarmed strike: a punch, kick, head-butt, or similar forceful blow (none of which count as weapons). On a hit, an unarmed strike deals &Reference[bludgeoning]{bludgeoning} damage equal to 1 + your &Reference[str]{Strength} modifier. You are proficient with your unarmed strikes.

As an action, you can magically assume the shape of a &Reference[beast]{beast} that you have seen before twice per short rest. [2nd] Max CR 1/4 (no flying or swimming speed) [4th] Max CR 1/2 (no flying speed) [8th] Max CR 1 You can stay in &Reference[beast]{beast} shape for [[floor( + @classes.druid.levels/2)]] hours before reverting back to your normal form (or as a bonus action earlier or if you fall &Reference[unconscious]{unconscious}, drop to 0 hit points, or die).
More Details

Starting at 2nd level, you can use your action to magically assume the shape of a beast that you have seen before. You can use this feature twice. You regain expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

Your druid level determines the beasts you can transform into, as shown in the Beast Shapes table. At 2nd level, for example, you can transform into any beast that has a challenge rating of 1/4 or lower that doesn’t have a flying or swimming speed.

Beast Shapes

LEVEL

MAX CR

LIMITATIONS

2nd

1/4

No flying or swimming speed

4th

1/2

No flying speed

8th

1

—


You can stay in a beast shape for a number of hours equal to half your druid level (rounded down). You then revert to your normal form unless you expend another use of this feature. You can revert to your normal form earlier by using a bonus action on your turn. You automatically revert if you fall &Reference[unconscious]{unconscious}, drop to 0 hit points, or die.

While you are transformed, the following rules apply:

  • Your game statistics are replaced by the statistics of the beast, but you retain your alignment, personality, and Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores. You also retain all of your skill and saving throw proficiencies, in addition to gaining those of the creature. If the creature has the same proficiency as you and the bonus in its stat block is higher than yours, use the creature’s bonus instead of yours. If the creature has any legendary or lair actions, you can’t use them.
  • When you transform, you assume the beast’s hit points and Hit Dice. When you revert to your normal form, you return to the number of hit points you had before you transformed. However, if you revert as a result of dropping to 0 hit points, any excess damage carries over to your normal form. For example, if you take 10 damage in animal form and have only 1 hit point left, you revert and take 9 damage. As long as the excess damage doesn’t reduce your normal form to 0 hit points, you aren’t knocked &Reference[unconscious]{unconscious}.
  • You can’t cast spells, and your ability to speak or take any action that requires hands is limited to the capabilities of your beast form. Transforming doesn’t break your concentration on a spell you’ve already cast, however, or prevent you from taking actions that are part of a spell, such as @Compendium[adv-with-droop.droops-spells.FDflAMyRgQXiGRBx]{call lightning}, that you’ve already cast.
  • You retain the benefit of any features from your class, race, or other source and can use them if the new form is physically capable of doing so. However, you can’t use any of your special senses, such as darkvision, unless your new form also has that sense.
  • You choose whether your equipment falls to the ground in your space, merges into your new form, or is worn by it. Worn equipment functions as normal, but the DM decides whether it is practical for the new form to wear a piece of equipment, based on the creature’s shape and size. Your equipment doesn’t change size or shape to match the new form, and any equipment that the new form can’t wear must either fall to the ground or merge with it. Equipment that merges with the form has no effect until you leave the form.

description.value:
You can use Wild Shape as a bonus action and you can use a bonus action to expend one spell slot to regain 1d8 HP per level of the spell slot expended.
More Details

When you choose this circle at 2nd level, you gain the ability to use Wild Shape on your turn as a bonus action, rather than as an action.

Additionally, while you are transformed by Wild Shape, you can use a bonus action to expend one spell slot to regain 1d8 hit points per level of the spell slot expended.

You have 3 luck points per long rest. Whenever you make an attack roll, an ability check, or a saving throw (or when an attack roll is made against you), you can spend one to roll an additional d20 and you choose which die to use. You can choose to spend luck points after you roll the die, but before the outcome is determined.

This flat iron rod has a button on one end. You can use an action to press the button, which causes the rod to become magically fixed in place. Until you or another creature uses an action to push the button again, the rod doesn't move, even if it is defying gravity. The rod can hold up to 8,000 pounds of weight. More weight causes the rod to deactivate and fall. A creature can use an action to make a DC 30 &Reference[str]{Strength} check, moving the fixed rod up to 10 feet on a success.

description.value: While wearing this cloak, you can use a bonus action to make it billow dramatically.
